div1.p: To the Honorable James D. Porter Assistant Secretary of State Washington

Sir I have just received "Shoe + Leather Circular dated April 6th 1886, and at there are no statistics at hand or indeed available to import information Jean only reply from impressions derived from long experience.

There are probably no articles of American leather manufacture used in Senegal at present. 1878 an American merchant named Matthew Bartlett sent two or three small Invoices of light fancy shoes + slippers which sold well, but on his retirement from the business which happened two or three

years later all such shipments were discontinued. The only American Merchant now doing business reguarly in Senegal in FC Butman E6q. N 34 Central St.Balton. All others have either failed up or been driven off by European competition. Mr. Butman for reasons which will appear hereafter has hitherto made no shipments of articles of leather manufacture.

There is at present no demand for leather in Senegal, but of Shoes the Consumption is quite large and rapidly increasing. Still finds are in request, but light fancy shoes are most wanted. small sizes are wanted, but for the most part they should be medium inclined to small. Very long huled plantation feel are not prevalent in this part of Africa. The principal reason

why shoes cannot with advantage be exported from America to Africa lies in the fact that excepting to a very limited extent as in the case of Hides + Bubber, Americans commet take the produce of the country in payment. American vessels consequently earn scarcly any freifht commanders, so that an outward voyage only can be counted on to pay all expenses and yield a profit. American Merchants under such conditions can only handle at a living profit a few staples, generally not much manufactured that are peculiary American, such as Tobacco, Lumber, and same kinds of provisions. It is next to impossible without taking produce in payment, as Europeans do to complete successfully against goods of European manufacture. Our Merchants are now obliged to deal only with the large European Houses who can give

Bills in payment and most of these large houses being always stocked with Goods of European manufacture which they are compelled to receive from their principals in Europ are of courses kenly interested to keep competing American Goods out of the market.

The principal production of Senegambia is peanuts, of which 7,000,000 bushels are said to be exported to Europe annually. For a few years subsequent to our Civil War a portion of this peanut trade in spite of our high tariff, was diverted to the United States. All our vessels then carried full and paying cargoes homewards, which enabled our merchants to deal with traders of small means, and introduce new articles in spite of the of the large European Houses. Senegal parts were at that time much frequented by American

vessels, and the business for all engaged in it including Merchants, Shipowners, Agents, Manufacturers and Supercagoes was thriving. But in time the wide margin of 32 cts per bushel affordd American Nutgrowers by are protective tariff had its effect and Africans disappeared gradually from our markets. Simultaneously our West African trade began to languish for lack of return cargoes, until are American Concern after another was obliged to withdraw with their vessels from a business which under the changed circumstances could no longer yield them a living profit. Perhaps I should state before clubing that the shoes now current here are of French and no dearer than ours. But they lack the style and finish that was house and on strictly even terms I am sure they could not compete. It is also worthy of note that children shoes are etting to be used in considerable quantities which perhaps more than any other cirucmstances indicates that there will soon be an increase in the quantity wanted. The prevalence of Chigres a species of flea. Which had lately been imported from the West Indies and burrows in the toes of the natives when supposed is also having considerable influence to compel the wearing of shoes among them.

Probably however the American nugrowing insterest is now so well established that if the duty which has it were repeated to murown the receipts of the farmerrs would suffer no sensible diminition, vechile if American Merchants could only be enbaled to ship enough of nuts to ballast their vessels it might give them a hold of this market sufficient to control it for all articles in the manufacture of which Americans are appeared to expeal.

Finally, there seems to be no reason but the one referred to why American Shoe dealers should not find as profitable market here for their wares as in any other foreign country, of like population and renounced. It will perhaps be a century before the Senegatint begin to manufacture shoes for themselves, but then purchasing dispabition and capacity are importing everyday. I have the honor to be Very truly Your Peter Stuckland U.S. Consul
